qas.question: What new standards of translation came with the 19th century?
Who observed that the policy became "the text, the whole text, and nothing but the text"?
What sort of passages were still left out of the supposed "whole" text?
What did the Victorians aim to remind the reader of their translations?

answers.text: that they were reading a foreign classic

qas.question: How did the translation of Rubaiyat achieve an Oriental flavor?

answers.text: by using Persian names and discreet Biblical echoes

qas.question: What banned standards of translation came with the 19th century?
Who ignored that the policy became "the text, the whole text, and nothing but the text"?
What sort of passages were left in the supposed "whole" text?

plausible_answers.text: that they were reading a foreign classic

qas.question: What did the Victorians aim to remind the writer of in their translations?

plausible_answers.text: by using Persian names and discreet Biblical echoes

qas.question: How did the translation of Rubaiyat disregard an Oriental flavor?

context: The 19th century brought new standards of <a0_0><b5_0>accuracy and style<b5_0/><a0_0/>. In regard to accuracy, observes <a1_0><b6_0>J.M. Cohen<b6_0/><a1_0/>, the policy became "the text, the whole text, and nothing but the text", except for any <a2_0><b7_0>bawdy<a2_0/> passages<b7_0/> and the addition of copious explanatory footnotes. In regard to style, the Victorians' aim, achieved through far-reaching metaphrase (literality) or pseudo-metaphrase, was to constantly remind readers <a3_0><b8_0>that they were reading a foreign classic<b8_0/><a3_0/>. An exception was the outstanding translation in this period, Edward FitzGerald's Rubaiyat of Omar Khayyam (1859), which achieved its Oriental flavor largely <a4_0><b9_0>by using Persian names and discreet Biblical echoes<b9_0/><a4_0/> and actually drew little of its material from the Persian original.
